article.headline: Little's late basket finishes Stanford rally
article.linkText: Stanford holds off Washington State in first round
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The third time wasn't a charm for Washington State.

Rob Little scored just his second basket of the game with 17 seconds left, helping Stanford rally for a 60-58 victory over the Cougars in the first round of the Pac-10 tournament Thursday night.

The loss prevented the Cougars (12-16) from completing a three-game sweep of the Cardinal this season. Washington State won both regular-season meetings for the first time since 1992-93.

"We're just thankful they didn't beat us a third time," said Chris Hernandez, who led Stanford with 18 points.

Matt Haryasz added 15 points and 12 rebounds and Nick Robinson had 13 points.

"They play good defense, so to finally get some shots going down, it's a good feeling," Haryasz said.

Thomas Kelati scored 20 points, including six 3-pointers, for the sixth-seeded Cougars. His 3-pointers tied the individual tournament mark shared by four others.

Washington State made 13 3-pointers, tying the tournament record set by Oregon last year.

"The game was pretty typical of our season," Cougars coach Dick Bennett said. "We had so many just like this down the stretch. To come from behind when it doesn't appear you're going to be able to was a credit to our program."

The third-seeded Cardinal (18-11) will meet No. 14 Washington in Friday's semifinals. The second-seeded Huskies held off No. 7 seed Arizona State 95-90 in overtime.

The Cardinal outscored Washington State 17-7 to start the second half and make its way back into the game. The Cougars led all the way in the first half.

Tied at 38-all, the Cougars committed a shot-clock violation and Hernandez hit a 3-pointer to give Stanford its first lead of the game with 12:26 remaining. His 3-pointer was part of a 10-point run that kept Stanford in front 46-38.

The Cougars shot 80 percent from 3-point range in the first half, with Kelati connecting on three in a row to start the game.

"I took it upon myself to get the team going," Kelati said.

But Stanford's defense clamped down on the senior guard for much of the second half.

The Cardinal couldn't silence Kelati completely, though. He made a 3-pointer -- his first basket of the second half -- to get the Cougars within 52-51 with 5:04 remaining. After Hernandez made two free throws, Kelati sank another 3-pointer -- his sixth -- from near the Cougars' bench to tie the game at 54.

"In the second half, they went to the zone. They extended the zone and we didn't make the right decisions," Kelati said.

Robinson scored for Stanford before Kelati's 3-point try popped in and out. Teammate Chris Schlatter picked him up, though, hitting a 3-pointer with a hand in his face to give Washington State a 57-56 lead with 1:12 remaining.

Robinson scored on a goaltending call against Jeff Varem to put Stanford back in front 58-57 with 52 seconds left. Varem made one of two free throws for a 58-all tie with 41 seconds left.

After a timeout, Little powered his way inside for the go-ahead basket. Schlatter's long jumper bounced off the rim as time expired.

"We were looking to take it to the basket," Hernandez said about the final play. "I was able to drive and someone switched out on me. Rob came in and sealed the weak side. I just dropped it in there and he finished the play."

The teams met in the first round for the second straight year; the Cardinal won 68-47 a year ago.

Injuries have hurt the Cardinal, with leading scorer Dan Grunfeld out for the season because of a torn knee ligament. The team is down to eight scholarship players and one walk-on, but the Cardinal has won 12 of its last 16 games.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
